What ARE you trying to communicate? I think you still don't quite get what proofs are. Proofs are literally equivalent to the colloquial definition of "proving something", or "having/presenting an argument". Proofs are not notation. Proofs are not formalism. Notation is formalism.

Now let's investigate your "faulty notation" case: well, what DID you wrongly notate?
That e.g. a < 0, but you actually meant to write a >= 0? Then that's simply faulty logic, a non-functional argument.

Proofs have to just hold logically, via their reasoning. That the symbols and so-called "non-symbols" you use for that are interchangeable is actually quite the fundamental math fact.

>>15024780
>no matter how many times you multiple 0 to anything
You're not multiplying 0. There is no 0 in the product.
The factorial starts at 1. 1! = 1, 2! = 1*2, 3! = 1*2*3.
So 0! doesn't equal 0 times anything, it equals the product of 0 numbers. Which is 1. If it were a product *including* 0, it would be 0. But it's not a product including 0, it's an empty product.
>And specifically means both
Yes, BOTH greater than or equal to 1 AND less than or equal to N.
0 does NOT satisfy this property, because it's not greater than or equal to 1.
The set of natural numbers greater than or equal to 1 AND less than or equal to 0 is not {0}, it's {}.
The product of {0} is indeed 0, but the product of {} is 1

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15023534
I've worked for the Feds (FEMA, DoD/DHS contractor, and State), state (department of health), and locals (was a finance analyst, became deputy city manager for a medium sized city, then did consulting for local govs).

For career advancement and pay, don't neglect local government. Everyone focuses on the Feds and the top 5 public policy schools send a ton of people there, but competition is a lot harder, advancement is much more difficult, in part because political appointees occupy the top stratum of positions, and pay is generally significantly worse. You live in expensive areas but even top GS grades are $110-160k. Meanwhile, with the Boomers retiring there is a big shortage of town managers, and it's easy to find listings up above $150k or even above $200k for those jobs. However, being town/county/city administrator or manager comes with a lot more politics. You have to answer resident's complaints, get shit on by the city council while they grand stand, etc. You also have to deal with getting your plans passed through the local council, which can be a pain, and while it is easy to find a new job, you so risk getting terminated for political reasons.

I think working in an affluent town would be incredibly tedious despite the high pay. The big challenge is dealing with all the entitled voters, especially if you're in New England and have an open town meeting (everyone with a valid ID is part of the town legislature).

Urban politics are pretty interesting though. I had to deal with a police force that was always beating people up or getting arrested for their own crimes, bitter union negotiations, BLM, big urban development projects, major budgetary shortfalls, then the revenue apocalypse of the early pandemic before the Feds came in and saved our asses. Planning for capital projects is a lot of fun, watching markets, rolling BANs, deciding when to sell debt, etc.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15025322
In contrast, the defense/intel work I did before sounds a lot more interesting, but I was just a cog in a giant system and it was unclear who actually read my work, if anyone. State was cool but moving countries all the time is rough on a family, so IDK if I would do the foreign service. I know they are hurting for people after Trump under hiring though and many people quitting. I know two people who had parents in the foreign service and it does seem like it can be really good for kids since they get exposed to a lot, but it sucks if you get hardship deployments.

FEMA was really exciting and I loved the work, but is no good for a marriage. You are on deployments fairly often, up to half a year or more for some positions. Early in a deployment you work 7 days a week, 12 hours a day. On big ones you can end up living out of military barracks. I personally found the fast pace intoxicating, it is what got me into government work and let me see how working in finance can let you work in any policy area, but I had to bail out when I got engaged.

TL;DR, consider local work. You can advance much more quickly and have a lot more impact. However, if you dislike politics and will respond poorly to being called simultaneously a racist, communist, etc. on local access TV at council meetings, then you might not enjoy advancing in that field.

I just started doing more direct work with schools as a consultant (only did higher level stuff as city CFO before, so they were just one department). Schools are neat because you have way more data on how your initiatives are actually effecting performance. That part is neat if you like social sciences in general. Plus, K-12 is the biggest source of state/local spending by a long shot. Teachers unions suck to negotiate with but it's still way better than the police, who are absolutely horrendous (I personally think police unions should be straight up illegal, you can't have two chains of command in a paramilitary organization)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15025345
Either way, get good with some data languages. A ton of government finance work is based on shitty Excel spreadsheets. If you actually know how to use Excel, which very few people in finance do, you can be an absolute rock star and do the work of 10 people. Learn how to use lookups, index/match, etc. Learn how to do SQL queries. This is much easier now that Excel has Power Query built in. M is a very easy language to use and you can do plenty with just drop down menus. I think Excel allows for most DAX functions to be used within it now too, so those are worth learning. Excel is a bad tool but it is so ubiquitous that you have to learn in. And since stuff is going to be on Excel you might as well learn Power BI too so that you can make your reports interactive and self updating off of SQL queries. Hook up your ERP to an automated dashboard and your Boomer boss will think you're an IT god.

R is really good to know too for more advanced modeling. I would also learn something that lets you do Monte Carlo analysis since it is very useful for expense projections and capital budgets.

It's amazing how little you need to learn to be a comparatively advanced finance wiz in government.

I'm actually considering leaving the industry to go for a research PhD (information theory or philosophy of information), but I did enjoy my work in government quite a bit. And even if I haven't loved consulting, I can make six figures working part time, which is not bad at all. There is a very high demand for people who both know their finance and who can code.

last_replies.com: Because you have an intuitive belief that you are a tiny thing somewhere inside your head and behind your eyes that is the same thing from one moment of time to another and that must somehow "jump" between those moments to maintain your identity through time. Since you feel that there is only one such thing, there must also be only one "now" and so the current moment must be somehow special because it's "inhabited" by this thing. threads.com:
An object from another stellar system intersects with Earth.
That object is estimated to be roughly the size of a typical Earth car.
It is made of something described as "heavier" than iron.
What are the odds, that a solid object, from another star system that intersects with Earth, is made of material heavier than iron?
Let's ignore the big factors and big unknowns.
What are the odds that any random group of elements the size of a car, within the known universe, are comprised of something "heavier" than iron. Let's assume that's any element with an atomic mass that is heavier than iron's most common isotope, yet capable of maintaining it's solid state through an Earth atmosphere collision, as apparently, this object did.

That rules out so much, but again, more questions arise. Could this be an isotope of something more abundant? Some state of hyper condensed hydrogen, perhaps?
I feel like such a thing wouldn't make it to the ocean in one piece without us knowing it broke apart and/or a nice fat explosion, occurring.

Let's just break it down to only stable known isotopes of elements that have higher atomic mass than common iron.
That leaves us with a small list of the trace elements in our Universe.
Probability applied at face value to that, seems telling. I'd like to agree with Avi Loeb's fantasy...

However, why couldn't this just be a crystal structure? Something that condensed under pressure, somewhere else, and was then released through an impact? Seems just as reasonable to me, as ET, if not more so, since there SHOULD be more of that type of ejecta floating around, than scientific space probes from aliens.

However, if I start to factor in the fact that this didn't hit the Sun or Jupiter... Things start to favor Avi's idea again... By the odds, something like that should hit one of our solar system's larger gravity wells, should it interact with our solar system at all.

What does /sci/ think? Are we going to find a car sized diamond or no?

but all the reasons you just listed are also reasons WHY you use steel. You don't want something 'more elastic' if you're building a skyscraper. structural mechanics are something they teach engineering students in their first semester. Normal, high grade steel has been tested and measured to an exact calculable soience in every system you can imagine. It's trustworthy, reliable, and best of all- it has billions of examples of it working within a given system. even if titanium was just as cheap as regular steel, you wouldn't use it over regular steel just because it has a bunch of added properties. It's specifically those different properties that make is usable for things that steel isn't good for. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15025221
>You don't want something 'more elastic' if you're building a skyscraper.
Yes you do. Because the deformation is either elastic or it's plastic, and elastic is always preferable. Titanium is still stronger.

If I give you a titanium rod you will not be able to bend it as easily as a rod in construction steel, or even stainless steel. On top of that titanium doesn't require maintenance like construction steel does.

The reason you use construction steel is because it's cheap and it does the job. Which is also why you don't use stainless steel when you don't have to (because it's more expensive).

Like mentioned by the other anon, Ferrari have chassis and engine parts made of titanium. Regular cars use regular steel for these parts.

It's a superior metal, it's just too expensive.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>15025092
>>15025129
he's asking about using it as dopant in steel alloys, not in place of steel
>>15025032
steel is basically iron carbide ceramic mixed in solidified iron, sort of like bricks held by mortar
elements that are commonly used in steel like the Ct or V have similar ionic radius (=size) and are chemically similar enough to iron, so they can mix properly in relatively wide ratios
adding titanium would make crystal structure a mangled mess and it would fall apart - like trying to fit cinderblocks diagonally into a brick wall
there are extremely specific ratios where it works - that's how you get superalloys (which is rare instance where steel could be alloyed with titanium)

Because in the Einsteinian-relativistic paradigm, an objective slowing down of the speed of light due to differences in density (= compression of the medium) is translated to a slowing down of time by GR, while a subjective slowing down of the speed of light due to motion of the observer is transformed into a deformation of space (and time).

The objective slowing down of light "due to gravity" was Einstein's original conception of light and gravity, with which he derived that light would bend under the effect of gravity.
This is in agreement with Newton's questions in his Opticks, to which he answered positively. In turn, Newton gave mechanical reason as to why light would slow down and what gravity is, which Einstein simply ignored, not being an a fan of aether.

The subjective slowing down is what is addressed by Ungs's paper.
Lorentz assumed an incompressible aether, whether as a simplifying assumption or because he believed it. Euler, before him, advocated for it to be a compressible medium.

No, the standard model is based on QFT, which does not handle bound states like protons and neutrons very well. threads.sub: Super black hole is eating a star for breakfast!
threads.com:
https://www.space.com/black-hole-eating-star-jet-points-earth

By Robert Lea published 25 minutes ago

Astronomers have made the most distant observation of a black hole ripping apart a star and feasting upon it, thanks to a jet of stellar "leftovers" blasted directly toward Earth.

Because the jet is directed straight at Earth, the violent destruction of the star by this black hole, which astronomers call a tidal disruption event (TDE), was observable in visible light. The discovery could therefore signal a new way to observe such extreme events that are usually only detected in high-energy light, like gamma-rays and X-rays.

TDEs occur when stars wander too close to black holes. The black hole tears apart the star with incredibly powerful tidal forces created by its gravitational influence. In around 1% of TDEs, the black hole also blasts out jets of plasma and radiation from its poles.

"We have only seen a handful of these jetted-TDEs and they remain very exotic and poorly understood events," Nial Tanvir, an astronomer at the University of Leicester in the U.K. and co-author on the new research, said in a statement(opens in new tab) from the European Southern Observatory (ESO), which operates some of the telescopes used in the research. "Astronomers are thus constantly hunting for these extreme events to understand how the jets are actually created and why such a small fraction of TDEs produce them."

The discovery of this TDE, dubbed AT2022cmc, came in February, when a survey telescope, the Zwicky Transient Facility (ZTF) in California, sent out an alert about an unusual source of visible light, which ESO's Very Large Telescope (VLT) in the Atacama Desert region of Northern Chile then jumped to examine. It's a common dynamic for astronomers: Survey telescopes like ZTF pan across the sky for signs of short-lived and extreme events, which more focused telescopes like the VLT can follow up on, observing in greater detail.
